.:.Audric10:. says:

KAPISTAHAN NG NUESTRO PADRE JESUS NAZARENO DE QUIAPO

Tema: ''YAPAK NG POONG NAZARENO, YAKAP NG SAMBAYANAN SA PAGBABAGONG BUHAY"

Schedule of Events

Quiapo Church's Schedule of Mass and Activities:

January 9, 2011 (Sunday - Black Nazarene Feast Day)

3:00AM - 12:00PM

3:00PM - 9:00PM

_____________________________________________________

Activities in Quirino Grandstand (Luneta):

January 08, 2011 (Saturday - Bisperas ng Kapistahan)

1:00PM - Start of the Kissing to the Black Nazarene

3:00PM - Band Parade

5:00PM - Healing Mass

8:00PM - Start of the Vigil

January 09, 2011 (Sunday - Black Nazarene Feast Day)

12:00AM - Continuation of the Vigil

3:00AM - Biblical Talk with Fr. Anton Pascual

4:00AM - Holy Hour

5:00AM - Continuation Biblical Talk with Fr. Anton Pascual

6:00AM - Concelebrated High Mass with Archbishop Gaudencio Cardinal Rosales

8:00AM - Procession of the Black Nazarene

_____________________________________________________

ANG RUTA PARA SA TRASLASYON 2011

* From Quirino Grandstand (Rizal Park)

* Left to Katigbak Drive going to Padre Burgos

* Left to Taft Avenue going McArthur Bridge

* Left to Palanca St. going Quezon Bridge

* Left to Quezon Blvd.

* Right to Arlegui St.

* Right to Fraternal St.

* Right to Vergara St.

* Left to Duque de Alba St.

* Left to Castillejos St.

* Left to Farnecio St.

* Right to Arlequi St.

* Left to Legarda St.

* Left to Aguila St.

* Right to Carcer St.

* Right to Hidalgo St. going to Plaza del Carmen

* Left to Bilibid Viejo going to Puyat St.

* Left to Guzman St.

* Right to Hidalgo St.

* Left to Barbosa St.

* Right to Globo de Oro St. going to Quezon Bridge;

* Right to Palanca St.

* Right to Villalobos St. going to Plaza Miranda going back to Quiapo Church

If you guys are ever going to participate in the Feast of the Black Nazarene, please make sure that you are:

1) Fully equipped in terms of survival gear and items. Bring a couple of clothes, face towels and lots of bottled water with you;

2) Physically and mentally ready. Well you can look at the pictures and say to yourself "I can do that too." Once you're in the actual event though, it's not that easy. People collapse just from heat exhaustion. Some unfortunate few even get trampled;

3) Always alert for thieves and pickpockets. Yes, even in this holy event unscrupulous people will still take advantage of other people's belongings.

To sum it all up, be careful out there. God bless you in your journey at the Feast of the Black Nazarene. Jot down all the schedules and print out the procession route for the feast just to be sure.

Originally posted ages ago.

.:.Audric10:. edited this topic ages ago.

Todos los SANTOS says:

PNB STO NINO EXHIBIT / PROCESSION 2011

THE FEAST of the Epiphany ends Advent. But the feast of the Child Jesus that ushers in the new year kicks off the fiesta frenzy in the country. The devotion to the Santo Niño is a unique Filipino expression of faith.

The Congregacion del Santissimo Nombre del Niño Jesus, founded in 1979 by Ben Farrales, which the United Nations providentially declared then as the International Year of the Child, is spreading the devotion to the Santo Niño.

Mel Chionglo, acclaimed filmmaker and this year’s chairman of the Congregacion board, joined by fiesta festivities chairman Jesse Nell and vice chair Ricky Miranda, emphasized that the underlying themes of faith, fun and fiesta are timeless.

The opening Mass is set Jan. 20, 5 p.m., to be celebrated by Cubao Bishop Honesto S. Ongtioco at the PNB Financial Center Chapel.

The theme for 2011 is “O, Niño Jesus Pag-asa sa Puso ng Bawat Pilipino” (O, Santo Niño, the Hope in the Heart of Every Filipino). Sub-themes will be introduced during the nine-day novena. Chionglo said a special altar will be put up at the grand lobby of the PNB Financial Center.

The Congregacion, whose founding chair is renowned fashion designer Ben Farrales, was joined by Willy Buhay, Dingdong Bautista, Dom Martin Gomez, Efren de José, Reynaldo Gutierrez, Mannie Punzalan, Sonny Viana, Leo Limpo and Bobby Valdomar in formally organizing the group. From a small group of devotees in the early ’70s who join with their own images the annual Santo Niño exhibition and procession in Malolos, Bulacan, organized by Fr. Miguel Paez, Ulay Tantoco and Dez Bautista, it has become a major church organization with over 40 members who swear to uphold its tenets.

They replicated the Malolos event by bringing the Santissimo Nombre del Niño Jesus to homes in Quezon City.

Cardinal Jaime Sin recognized it as an official church organization in Oct. 27, 1979. Every year on the same date, members renew their vows.

Chapel, fiesta

Now, 32 years later, the Congregacion has its Santo Niño Violago Chapel, donated by Oscar and Bootsie Violago and located at E. Rodriguez Ave., Quezon City. The chapel has been recently refurbished by the Violagos.

Its annual Fiesta del Santo Niño has become an anticipated and a consistently well-attended religious experience both for local and foreign tourists.

“All of us involved in the Congregacion are humbled to have seen what faith, hope and charity through the Santo Niño mean,” Chionglo said.

Grand procession

A major highlight is the annual exhibit of Santo Niño images at Long Gallery of the PNB Financial Center. Those wishing to participate must register with the secretariat at PNB Exhibit Center, Jan. 17-19, 9 a.m.- 7 p.m. They can also get in touch with Daisy Reyes at tel. 5259126.

The celebration is capped with a long procession on Jan. 30. Some 300 well-decorated carozas will participate.

“As far as I know it’s the only procession where the throng is welcomed by families and countless other believers who bring out their images of the Santo Niño, have them line the procession route, and show this single act of outpouring of gratitude and homage to the Child Jesus,” Chionglo said. “It is an amazing and inspiring sight.”

This year’s Hermanos Mayores are José Ferdinand and Patricia Rojas, Consuls Louie and Mellie Ablaza, Oscar and Bootsie Violago, William and Mila How, Renato and Vicky Magadia, Ed and Fe de Guia, Ricardo and Juliet Santos, Ma. Theresa Palado, Albert and Erlinda Rosal, David and Cora Yu, Dr. Joel Mendez and Vivien Raneses, Paulino Tan, Johnny and Carol Rogge, Mark Louie and Jennifer Palado-Santiago, Gloria Binay, Mario and Jennilyn Buela, Roberto Tapalla, Rodrigo Catamora Sr., Edward Teng, Marcosa Sanchez, Steve Chan, Alberto and Herminia Co, Flaviano Calonzo, Alfredo and Flor Go.

Officers of the Congregacion for 2011, aside from Farrales and Chionglo, are Jing Chua, president; Steve de Leon, vice-president; John Enriquez, secretary; Ricky Miranda, treasurer; Bob de Castro, Chito Ilagan, Venson Nobrera and Deo Pamilar, board members.

SF_Catholic says:

www.facebook.com/?ref=home#!/pages/Rolling-Rosary/2234611...

M. Northington/M.Connolly

Description Calling all the Children of God Now...

MARY IS LISTENING....

This is a year of prayer and hope! Our Blessed Mother is here for our protection and we want to show our appreciation. Come together in prayer, faith and hope. " COME TO THE FOOT OF THE CROSS" Mary said to St. Catharine Laboure ~ Let us all THANK our Blessed Mother on 5/31/11 @ 8PM

JESUS told him "I AM THE WAY AND THE TRUTH AND THE LIFE. NO ONE COMES TO THE FATHER EXCEPT THROUGH ME." (John 14.6)

MISSION: In honor of our Mother....LIGHT UP THE WORLD WITH US

as we create a wave of Rolling Rosary prayers that circle the earth to say Thank you uniting her children in Faith, HOPE, and prayer! What a wonderful Mother's day gift it would be if we could thank her with prayers. CATCH THE WAVE...celebrate with the world!

ANNUAL WORLDWIDE

CANDLELIGHT ROLLING ROSARY in

HONOR of OUR BLESSED MOTHER

WHEN: MAY 31

TIME: 8PM

WHERE: Churches, universities, nursing homes and neighborhoods - your choosing.... As long as we join in prayer...

Bring a Friend to join on this special day ~ Bring a battery operated candle & light up the world. How joyful will Mary Be?

"For I know well the plans I mind for you says the Lord, Plans for welfare, not for woe! Plans to give you a future full of HOPE." Jeremiah 29:11

St. Louis deMontfort, in his book "The Secret of the Rosary" writes, "Somebody who says his Rosary alone only gains the Merit of one Rosary, but if he says it together with thirty other people he gains the merit of thirty Rosaries. This is the law of public prayer."

After reading that, who wouldn't want the merit of THOUSANDS of Rosaries?

Feel the comfort of our Blessed Mother as she shelters us with her Mantle....AND teaches us to Trust and Love God and others. Come.

The Memorare Prayer

Remember, O most gracious Virgin Mary,that never was it known that anyone who fled to your protection,implored your help or sought your intercession,was left unaided.

Inspired with this confidence,I fly to you, O Virgin of virgins, my Mother;to you do I come, before you I stand, sinful and sorrowful.

O Mother of the Word Incarnate,despise not my petitions,but in your mercy hear and answer me.

Amen.

The Miraculous Medal

O Mary, conceived without sin, pray for us who have recourse to thee.

"O Mary,conceived without Sin, Pray for us who have recourse to thee,

O,Mary,conceived without sin, pray for us who have recourse to thee,

Update on Lipa:

Report of the Commission on the Doctrine of the Faith (ECDF)

CBCP Plenary Meeting, January 2011

(Excerpts)

Some responses of Cardinal William Levada and Archbishop Luis Ladaria, SJ, prefect and secretary, respectively, of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith to queries of the bishops during the visita ad limina apostolorum (November 22, 2010).

II. Apparitions of Our Lady in Lipa

Archbishop Ramon Arguelles has recently formed a commission to investigate once again the events of the Carmel of Lipa (1948). Since the 1991 committee set up by the late Archbishop Mariano Gaviola did not conclude its work, it is only proper that such a study be re-opened. A definitive verdict would surely have positive pastoral consequences.

We could recall these words of Archbishop Gaviola in his letter of April 16, 1995 to Bishop Salvador Quizon, the Chairman of the committee: “In short, the Special Committee was supposed to focus their investigation only on reports about Lipa Carmel that took place AFTER the promulgation of the same Decree of 1952 (underscoring in the original). However, I also authorized the Committee to gather testimonies of personal witnesses to the Lipa Carmel events in 1948 and the early years thereafter. Far from wanting to impugn the findings of the Episcopal Commission, we simply wanted to know for ourselves what would the testimonies of witnesses under the present circumstance compared to what they might have said under the circumstances when they were investigated by the CBCP Episcopal Commission.”

(SGD) + LUIS ANTONIO G. TAGLE, D.D.

Chairman, ECDF

source:Bro Marwill Llasos OP Blogspot

Marc",) says:

Welcome To Archbishop Giuseppe Pinto, Apostolic Nuncio To The Philippines

July 17, 2011

MANILA, Philippines — His Holiness, Pope Benedict XVI, officially appointed His Excellency, Archbishop Giuseppe Pinto, as the new Apostolic Nuncio to the Philippines on May 10, 2011. Archbishop Pinto succeeded Archbishop Edward Joseph Adams, who ended his term as Papal Nuncio to the Philippines on May 7, 2011, and has been reassigned to Greece. Archbishop Pinto arrived in the Philippines on July 15, 2011, and was welcomed by His Eminence, Gaudencio B. Cardinal Rosales, outgoing CBCP President Nereo Odchimar, and other leaders of the Catholic Church.

Archbishop Pinto, previously assigned to Chile since 2007, is the 15th Papal Representative and the 10th Apostolic Nuncio to the Philippines. He entered the Diplomatic Service of the Holy See on May 1, 1984, and has served successively in Papua New Guinea, Argentina, and the Vatican City State Secretariat. He also served as Apostolic Nuncio to Cape Verde, Senegal, Mali, and Guinea-Bissau, and was Apostolic Delegate to Mauritania.

Born on May 26, 1952, or 59 years ago in Bari, Italy, Archbishop Pinto was ordained a priest on April 1, 1978. He holds a doctorate in Canon Law and is fluent in Italian, French, English, and Spanish.

Upon his arrival in the Philippines, Archbishop Pinto said he is happy to be in a country made up by people of profound faith, vowing to “work to bring this faith with me and work together with the Filipino people.” The Papal Nuncio or Papal Legate enjoys seniority of precedence over other Ambassadors in the Philippines; he is Dean of the Diplomatic Corps. In addition to his diplomatic duties, he also serves as the liaison between the Holy See and the Roman Catholic Diocesan Episcopate in the country.

We welcome His Excellency, Archbishop Giuseppe Pinto, as the new Apostolic Nuncio to the Philippines, and wish him all the best and success in all his endeavors. MABUHAY!

MARIAN Events says:

ASH WEDNESDAY 2012

Ash Wednesday marks the beginning of the Season of Lent. It is a season of penance, reflection, and fasting which prepares us for Christ's Resurrection on Easter Sunday, through which we attain redemption.

Why we receive the ashes

Following the example of the Nine vites, who did penance in sackcloth and ashes, our foreheads are marked with ashes to humble our hearts and reminds us that life passes away on Earth. We remember this when we are told

"Remember, Man is dust, and unto dust you shall return."

Ashes are a symbol of penance made sacramental by the blessing of the Church, and they help us develop a spirit of humility and sacrifice.

The distribution of ashes comes from a ceremony of ages past. Christians who had committed grave faults performed public penance. On Ash Wednesday, the Bishop blessed the hair shirts which they were to wear during the forty days of penance, and sprinkled over them ashes made from the palms from the previous year. Then, while the faithful recited the Seven Penitential Psalms, the penitents were turned out of the church because of their sins -- just as Adam, the first man, was turned out of Paradise because of his disobedience. The penitents did not enter the church again until Maundy Thursday after having won reconciliation by the toil of forty days' penance and sacramental absolution. Later, all Christians, whether public or secret penitents, came to receive ashes out of devotion. In earlier times, the distribution of ashes was followed by a penitential procession.

The Ashes

The ashes are made from the blessed palms used in the Palm Sunday celebration of the previous year. The ashes are christened with Holy Water and are scented by exposure to incense. While the ashes symbolize penance and contrition, they are also a reminder that God is gracious and merciful to those who call on Him with repentant hearts. His Divine mercy is of utmost importance during the season of Lent, and the Church calls on us to seek that mercy during the entire Lenten season with reflection, prayer and penance.

MARIAN Events says:

MASS READINGS for June 24, 2012 (Solemnity of the Nativity of Saint John the Baptist)

Book of Isaiah 49:1-6.

Hear me, O islands, listen, O distant peoples. The Lord called me from birth, from my mother's womb he gave me my name.

He made of me a sharp-edged sword and concealed me in the shadow of his arm. He made me a polished arrow, in his quiver he hid me.

You are my servant, he said to me, Israel, through whom I show my glory.

Though I thought I had toiled in vain, and for nothing, uselessly, spent my strength, Yet my reward is with the LORD, my recompense is with my God.

For now the LORD has spoken who formed me as his servant from the womb, That Jacob may be brought back to him and Israel gathered to him; And I am made glorious in the sight of the LORD, and my God is now my strength!

It is too little, he says, for you to be my servant, to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and restore the survivors of Israel; I will make you a light to the nations, that my salvation may reach to the ends of the earth.

Copyright © Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, USCCB

Psalms 139(138):1b.2ab.3ab.13ab-14ab.14c-15abc.

O LORD, you have probed me, you know me:

You know when I sit and when I stand;

You understand my thoughts from afar.

My journeys and my rest you scrutinize,

With all my ways you are familiar.

Truly you have formed my inmost being;

You knit me in my mother's womb.

I give you thanks that I am fearfully, wonderfully made;

Wonderful are your works.

My soul also you knew full well;

Nor was my frame unknown to you

When I was made in secret,

When I was fashioned in the depths of the earth.

Copyright © Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, USCCB

Acts of the Apostles 13:22-26.

Then he removed him and raised up David as their king; of him he testified, 'I have found David, son of Jesse, a man after my own heart; he will carry out my every wish.'

From this man's descendants God, according to his promise, has brought to Israel a savior, Jesus.

John heralded his coming by proclaiming a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel;

and as John was completing his course, he would say, 'What do you suppose that I am? I am not he. Behold, one is coming after me; I am not worthy to unfasten the sandals of his feet.'

"My brothers, children of the family of Abraham, and those others among you who are God-fearing, to us this word of salvation has been sent.

Copyright © Confraternity of Christian Doctrine, USCCB

Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Luke 1:57-66.80.

When the time arrived for Elizabeth to have her child she gave birth to a son.

Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had shown his great mercy toward her, and they rejoiced with her.

When they came on the eighth day to circumcise the child, they were going to call him Zechariah after his father,

but his mother said in reply, "No. He will be called John."

But they answered her, "There is no one among your relatives who has this name."

So they made signs, asking his father what he wished him to be called.

He asked for a tablet and wrote, "John is his name," and all were amazed.

Immediately his mouth was opened, his tongue freed, and he spoke blessing God.

Then fear came upon all their neighbors, and all these matters were discussed throughout the hill country of Judea.

All who heard these things took them to heart, saying, "What, then, will this child be?" For surely the hand of the Lord was with him.

The child grew and became strong in spirit, and he was in the desert until the day of his manifestation to Israel.
